title: Email DMARC Policy Checker
subtitle: Check DMARC policy for email authentication, analyze deliverability impact, and get implementation recommendations

policy.title: Policy Configuration
policy.coverageDescription: Percentage of mail subject to policy

failureOptionsValues.0: Generate reports if all mechanisms fail
failureOptionsValues.1: Generate reports if any mechanism fails
failureOptionsValues.d: Generate reports if DKIM check fails
failureOptionsValues.s: Generate reports if SPF check fails

reporting.title: Email Reporting Configuration
reporting.aggregateNotConfiguredHint: Missing aggregate reporting - consider adding rua=
reporting.forensicDescription: Real-time failure reports with message samples

noRecord.title: No DMARC Record Found
noRecord.message: No DMARC record was found for {domain}

impacts.reputation: May affect email reputation with major providers
impacts.visibility: Missing visibility into email authentication failures
impacts.recommendation: Consider implementing DMARC starting with p=none for monitoring

policies.none: none: Monitoring mode - no action taken on failures, only reporting
policies.quarantine: quarantine: Failed emails are marked as spam or moved to quarantine
policies.reject: reject: Failed emails are rejected outright, strongest protection

bestPractices.startNone: Start with p=none to monitor without affecting email delivery
bestPractices.gradual: Gradually move to p=quarantine, then p=reject as you fix issues
bestPractices.reporting: Set up aggregate reporting (rua=) to track authentication results
bestPractices.testAlignment: Test DKIM and SPF alignment before enforcing strict policies
bestPractices.subdomain: Consider subdomain policy (sp=) if subdomains send email

alignment.relaxed: Relaxed (r): Allows organizational domain matches (subdomain.example.com matches example.com)
alignment.strict: Strict (s): Requires exact domain match for DKIM/SPF alignment

issues.thirdParty: Third-party senders may fail if not properly configured in SPF/DKIM
issues.forwarding: Email forwarding can break SPF alignment
issues.mailingLists: Mailing lists may modify messages, breaking DKIM signatures
issues.percentage: Use pct= to gradually roll out enforcement (default 100%)
